citations.narrative:
In the drive through area of the park there are several areas of the perimeter fence which are in need of repair. The
perimeter fence near the giraffe enclosure is incomplete and has a wide gap which potentially allows direct access to the
giraffe enclosure. A creek channel in the drive through section near the camel area is fenced with panels which are
approximately six feet high and constructed with gaps that would allow passage of animals or unauthorized persons
through the gate. The perimeter fence from the drive through entrance to the hyena enclosure is not of sufficient height to
meet AWA requirements and is not currently maintained in adequate condition. A gate in the perimeter fence next to the
giraffe enclosure is not of sufficient height to meet requirements. The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it
protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and
having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the
animals in the facility. Facilities housing potentially dangerous animals must have a fence at least 8 feet in height. These
requirements apply to all sections of the fence, including gates.

In an indoor enclosure housing two red kangaroo, there was an excessive accumulation of feces and waste covering the
floor area. This is a potential source of contamination to the enclosed animals. Excreta and feces shall be removed from
primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize
disease hazards and to reduce odors. The licensee is to ensure that an adequate cleaning and sanitization schedule is
maintained at all times.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.
In an indoor housing area for a common eland, there was an excessive accumulation of feces and waste covering the
floor area. The animal could not enter the housing area for feed and water without coming into contact with the feces and
waste. Excreta and feces shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of
the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. The licensee is to ensure that an
adequate cleaning and sanitization schedule is maintained at all times.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
In the drive through area of the park there are several areas of the perimeter fence which are in need of repair. The 
perimeter fence near the giraffe enclosure is incomplete and has a wide gap which potentially allows direct access to the 
giraffe enclosure. A creek channel in the drive through section near the camel area is fenced with panels which are

protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and 
having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the 
animals in the facility. Facilities housing potentially dangerous animals must have a fence at least 8 feet in height. These 
requirements apply to all sections of the fence, including gates. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
In an indoor enclosure housing two red kangaroo, there was an excessive accumulation of feces and waste covering the 
floor area. This is a potential source of contamination to the enclosed animals. Excreta and feces shall be removed from 
primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize 
disease hazards and to reduce odors. The licensee is to ensure that an adequate cleaning and sanitization schedule is 
maintained at all times. 
Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
 
In an indoor housing area for a common eland, there was an excessive accumulation of feces and waste covering the 
floor area. The animal could not enter the housing area for feed and water without coming into contact with the feces and 
waste. Excreta and feces shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of 
the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. The licensee is to ensure that an 
adequate cleaning and sanitization schedule is maintained at all times. 
Corrected at the time of the inspection.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: GRAY WOLF / GREY WOLF / TIMBER WOLF
